rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:2
rsbNotes.text: 78:2 in a parable. The writer means that he will recount the events of the past in a poetic way designed to instruct the hearts of distant generations.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:3
rsbNotes.text: 78:3 told us. Instruction was disseminated in his family from generation to generation (Deut. 6:4–9; 32:7).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:5
rsbNotes.text: 78:5 testimony . . . law. God established a relationship with His people based on grace alone. In this context He gave them laws to live by and to show their gratefulness to Him. These laws are summarized in the Ten Commandments (Ex. 20; Deut. 5).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:6
rsbNotes.text: 78:6 tell them to their children. See note on v. 3.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:7
rsbNotes.text: 78:7 keep his commandments. The object of the history lesson is not merely antiquarian, but to deepen the faith and obedience of God’s people.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:9
rsbNotes.text: 78:9 Ephraimites. This verse should be compared to vv. 67, 68, where the choice of Judah is coupled with the rejection of Ephraim.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:10
rsbNotes.text: 78:10 God’s covenant. God promised to protect His people if they obeyed the terms of His covenant, but to destroy them if they disobeyed (Deut. 27:9–28:68).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:13
rsbNotes.text: 78:13 He divided the sea. Chief among the great acts of God was the deliverance from Egypt by which God rescued His people from slavery and brought them into their own land. The Red Sea crossing was the greatest demonstration of God’s power in the past and, accordingly, was often called to memory by psalmists and prophets.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:18
rsbNotes.text: 78:18 tested God. Time and time again Israel grumbled about the food in the wilderness, and God provided for their needs (Ex. 16).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:20
rsbNotes.text: 78:20 Can he also give bread. God’s provision of water in the wilderness should have led to faith and trust. Instead the Israelites tested the Lord by asking for food (cf. John 6:25–58).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:21
rsbNotes.text: 78:21 full of wrath. Rebellion against the Lord led to His judgment (Num. 11:1–3). After judging the people, He returned with His grace (vv. 23–39), but grace led only to further rebellion (vv. 40, 41). This is the story of Israel throughout the Old Testament, perhaps best represented in the Book of Judges (see Judg. 2:6–23). Heb. 12:1–12 reminds us that God chastises those He loves.
